p:
SARS-CoV-2 is shown to be more sensitive to type I interferon (IFN) than SARS-CoV due to the absence of two important IFN antagonists [53]. We examine the impact of IFN as treatment intensification with the above antiviral therapy by increasing the killing due to the innate immune response (i.e. the value of
ω
in the model) by 5 folds. We find that increasing the killing by the innate immune response can largely suppress the viral replication (compare Fig. 8A,C). Under IFN treatment, the viral load could be significantly reduced with 60% drug efficacy (lopinavir/ritonavir or remdesivir). The result suggests that early treatment with a combination of IFN and other antiviral drugs might be promising against novel coronavirus infection.
